reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Masterplan is an action/strategy game focused on pulling off different heists and set in the 70s. If you enjoyed games like Payday 2 or Monaco you’ll most likely enjoy this one, too, even if they are entirely different games. Still, this game can easily hold its own and has more than enough content for an Early Access version.

The comparison to aforementioned games isn’t a completely honest comparison because Payday 2 is a first-person shooter focused on a whole lot of shooting (if things go wrong, that is) and Monaco is really more about stealth than tactics. But The Masterplan masterfully combines several of the elements used in these games: first of all, you view the action from a top-down perspective and there are several ways to finish a mission; guns blazing, with careful planning or - if things go wrong - a combination of both. You will also holdup civilians and cops among other things related to heists.

You can walk freely to wherever you want, as long as it’s not towards a place that raises suspicion. You’ll control several goons, which can be controlled individually or as a group. It’s usually a good idea to just walk around and see where everything is located before taking any action. Once you have an idea of what to do you can strategically place your goons and let them do what they’re supposed to do.
As an example you could have a goon set up near the entrance of the place that holds people who are entering or about to leave hostage, one that holds the store manager hostage (which you can then control to open things, for example) and another one could knock the store manager out once he’s done with that (or before that, and have a goon open the door him-/herself). There are many ways to complete the heist, and there are many ways a heist can go wrong. The store manager could call the cops, which will then arrive shortly after, making it nearly impossible to get out without killing anyone. Do something suspicious on camera and again, the police will be alerted. Or civilians could see an unconscious or dead body and, yup, could call the cops.
It’s a game that requires a good bit of strategy but thankfully the developers have implemented a feature to slow down time for people that usually don’t play strategy games or have a difficult time improvising when things go wrong. It’s a feature that doesn’t use a time mechanic so you could play the entire heist in slow motion if you wanted to. It makes the game very accessible to all sorts of players.
The maps aren’t that big to begin with and that’s actually something that I liked. It’s hard to manage your characters when they’re miles apart from each other. Some of the maps of the later heist missions are just big enough for them to become cluttered. But I think there will actually be bigger maps in the final version. I just hope they don’t become too big.
There’s also a hideout map where you can eventually hire new goons and do some other stuff, and this is also where the game tells you about the game’s mechanics, besides the tutorial level (which basically explains the controls).

This Early Access version has 5 different heists, ranging from very simple to pretty difficult. There are a few features missing right now, like goons having specific skills, a connecting story and, obviously, more heist locations. The developers states that there is about 1,5-2 hours of gameplay in this version and I agree. But you could add an hour or even a few hours more if you want to play things in a different way. So far, this version is already extremely polished and it runs great without any problems. I also didn’t encounter any bugs so far, but maybe I’m just lucky. Who knows ?

The graphics are 2D and shown from a top-down perspective. The characters lack a bit of personality because of this but the graphics are just beautiful in general. It has a nice 70s look mixed with what looks like some sort of comic book effect(s). It’s absolutely gorgeous to look at, and it’s all made with higher resolutions in mind.
The soundtrack consists of some smooth songs that have a jazzy feel that reminded me of old school heist movies. And that sounds exactly what they’re aiming for. So they did an excellent job there. Same goes for the sound effects which have an authentic feeling to them.

The Masterplan is on its way to become one of my favorite indie games. There’s still some work to be done, and I’m not talking about fixes here, but more about adding (final) content. This current version is already very stable and very playable and if you enjoy strategy games or heist games then this is a game you just must own. You can clearly see this game was made with passion and that’s absolutely something that should be rewarded. And the best way to do this is to just buy the game.

[Rating: 87/100]

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Masterplan is a top-down tactical heist game set in the 70's from Finnish developer Shark Punch that is currently available in Early Access. In The Masterplan you manage your crew (at the beginning you have two heisters but you can hire more as you progress) as they take on heists anywhere from a convenience store to a high end jewellery store to a drug lord's mansion. The Masterplan lets you choose your own playstyle and you can either go for the stealth approach (highly recommended) or you can go in guns blazing.

+Awesome hand drawn graphics that really capture the game's 1970's feel
+Really cool threatening/hostage system which allows you to control other characters by pointing a gun at them
+You can enter slow-motion at any point in order to plan your next moves
+Lots of objects in the levels can be interacted with, power can be cut off, CCTV can be disabled etc.
+Currently quite a few different and diverse heist targets all of which can be replayed as many times as you want
+Quite a few weapons to unlock as you progress through the game
+Money you earn in missions can be spent on new heisters or weapons for your ammo which provides the player good motive to find all of the money in any given level
+The heisters you can hire have different abilities, strengths and weapons depending on how much they cost
+You're provided with hints/intel on your target location while the game loads which is very handy
+Simple control scheme
+Reasonably regular updates
+The devs are active in the forums

+/-Cleaner fees are extremely high, personally I don't mind this because I prefer playing stealth in this game and this just forces me to do that more

-No options menu, that means no graphical options other than a fullscreen toggle, no way of changing controls and no way of changing the volume in-game apart from toggling it on or off completely
-Pathfinding isn't great, your characters will always take the fastes route which often means they'll just stop at a locked door rather than go a different way which isn't locked
-It has some issues with crashing, I experienced three crashes in the first twenty minutes
-Unconcious enemies wake up annoyingly quickly, within about thirty seconds of being knocked out

Verdict:
7.5

Despite a few issues this is a great tactical heist game with awesome hand drawn graphics, great gameplay and loads of potential going forward.

***This review was written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

Would I reccomend this to a friend? Nope. This game was removed from early acccess too soon. Review is for v1.2.2

Unstable.
Crashes too often (Seems to be a memory leak. Perfomance gets worse the longer you play), especialy on the later levels that take longer to complete. Can't complete my current mission (3rd to last) as the game will crash before the mission can be completed. By design, you can't save durring missions. I'm ok with the lack of saving, but having to rush to try and finish a level before the game will crash, is not ok.

Controls are bad.
Opening/closing doors are a large source of frustration. Game uses swinging doors with physics. To open a door to a room, you have to walk in to the door and then in to the room to open the door all the way. Until the door swings out of your face, you can't see anything past the door.
Closing a door when facing it is often a two step proccess. You click the door to close it, and it swings on to your goon. He then has to turn away and walk away from the door as it will push him in the back if he does't move quick enough or of another goon is too close and blocking his path. Once the goon has cleared the door jam, he can turn around to face the door to lock it. This process takes WAY TOO LONG to complete. Have fun doing this when you want to lock enemies in a room before they can rush the door, push it open and punch your goons silly.
Due to the bad controls, you are required to use two or more goons to do what should be simple tasks for a single goon. One to close/lock the door, second or third to hold a gun on the enemy to delay them breaking control. Sure you can knock everyone out and drop them in the room you plan to lock them in. You end up having to do that anyway, but it feels forced as the other method is so bad.

Pathing can be bad. Tell a goon to backup to move a small distance away from an enemy or anything actualy. Instead of turning and moving to that spot, they will try to move far away (often in to another room) and then loop back to the spot you told them to move to. It then turns in to move, cancel order, move again.

General bad stuff you can find in this game.
Hire goons based on their stats, yet once you hire them you can not see those stats again.

Goons can be killed by gunfire (including your own). OK that's fine. Goons can be killed by melee attacks. These are the same attacks that only temporarily knock out the enemies. Can't revive your goons durring missions, nor can you carry them back to the hideout to be revived. They can be killed from being punched with bare fists. Not OK.

Enemies can have melee weapons (baton) yet will not drop them when knocked out or killed.  Late game you find 1 brass kncukle. Whoopty-doo.

Achievement to hire enough goons to reach a team of 6. What's the point when you can only bring 4 on any mission. Outside of that achievement, there is zero reason to have more than 4 goons at a time.

Pro's.
Sound and Art are nice.

Edit: Went to double check the version of the game v1.2.1 or v1.2.2 and now it crashes on launch. Avoid this game.

reviewText:
Imagine taking GTA5, Payday 2, Battlefield: Hardline, Doorkickers, and Frozen Synapse, and throw them into a bowl and mix them all together, then put them in the oven at 350 degrees for about 20 minutes.

The result would be some nasty stuff nobody would ever want, but at least it would give you good reason to not bake ever again and play The Masterplan instead.

I've watched and played this game since they jumped into Early Access last year and enjoyed every minute of it. I suppose that micro-managing a robbery/heist wouldn't sound too exciting, but the very first time you walk out with that cash in hand (and no cops giving you a hard time), it gets you hooked.

There are many different ways to complete each heist, but eventually it all boils down to busting through the front door with SMG's, Shotguns, and Rifles, and mowing down everyone, greatly hoping that you make it out with at least half the loot. OR, you could go the stealthy methodical route with silenced pistols and tranquilizer guns, taking down cameras and stuffing people into rooms. Each heist has their own way of making you think, with their own way of rewarding you by doing things by the book. Some heists you absolutely have to go in armed to the teeth, and some will brutally punish you for not sneaking your way in.

The Soundtrack is simple and somewhat dynamic, but still does its job good. Makes the setting feel like a real 70's action flick. Sadly, neither Austin Powers nor Foxxy Cleopatra make a cameo in-game.

5/5 Stars
11/10 Would heist a kiosk again
$50 out of $100,000 loot taken, with a 75% evidence cleaning fee.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW BUILD 1 16/09/2014

The Masterplan is a game where you pull of various heists as you see fit, the heists can range from small shops to jewelry stores and even to warehouses (No banks or such are currently in the game) there are as of now 4 heists to pull off and they are designed really well. You can pull of these heists in various ways such as walking in the front door and pulling your gun out and murder everyone inside, of course anyone who sees you doing this will imediately call the cops and you will have 30 seconds to get the hell out. Or you could walk inside, wait for the owner to go someone secluded, follow them, take them hostage and then get your friend to beat the hell out of them and then continue with only the customers to worry about. But of course some are much more difficult as guard will be involved.

-Gameplay-
You control various men (in the future you will be able to hire your own men and such but for now you are given 'goons' on different heists) using your mouse and you tell them what to do and they do it. If you pull out a gun and aim at someone then they will freeze meaning they won't move and now you can control them but if you lose LOS a meter that slowly drains will drain much faster and when it runs out they will make a run for it or if they have a weapon attack you. There are various keys that open different doors and security guards that will watch cameras for illegal activity.

-Conclusion-

This is a very well made game even for Early Access, I have high hopes for this game and definately reccommend picking it up now even though there are only 4 heists because they are highly replayable as you can approach in loads of ways and possibly improve on your last run. There are of course quite a few bugs and issues such as if the game lags it causes the characters to fly across the screen which is hilarious until it screwes you over, also something I 'hate' at the moment is if 'you' call the cops from a phone even if you haven't even entered the building yet when the cops turn up they will kill you on sight. I learned this because I wanted to see how they responded to calls incase it went south but the cops wanted to shoot first and ask questions later.

For now I give it an 8/10 for being fun, unique and amazing even if it is a tad buggy at times. Hopefully there will be some sort of MP as that would be incredible for this type of game.

reviewText:
The Masterplan Review
The Rundown
- So, what is 'The Masterplan?'
The Masterplan is a 'Top Down' '2D' 'Heist' 'Strategy' game by 'Shark Punch' with a very interesting concept, with a okay execution.

- Is it good?
Yes, i enjoyed my experience with the game, However there are a few problems, To avoid leaving a bitter taste after reading this, i will go through the bad parts First.

The Bad
Technical Issues - Crashes
Game crashed often with no seemingly obvious cause. Also, the game seemed to black-screen when Tabbing out in full-screen.
Technical Issues - Frame Rate Drops
The frame rate tanks in areas some times and other times, the same place, same condition, it's fine.
Technical Issues - No Settings Menu
The lack of a volume slider or graphical setting menu was frustrating, the only options available are 'Music On/Off' and 'Toggle Fullscreen'.
Technical Issues - Fails To Remember Settings Selected
Each launch you are greeted with blasting music even if previously you have selected to have it turned off.
Technical Issues - Fails To Issue Achievements
Multiple achievements were failed to be issued upon completion of asked events. mainly the 'Complete _ Branch' achievements.
Gameplay - 'Loud' Combat Is Clunky
There are some problems with loud combat, say if a enemy walks around a corner and re-appears, your character will not continue shooting and your characters will constantly shoot each other if they are too close, rather than moving to the side. Also if a enemy is too close, you will not intimidate or hit them.
Gameplay - 'Stealth' Combat Is Un-Realistic
Non-Suppressed weapons have a VERY VERY small alert range, You can Shoot a rifle at someone and hit from just outside their cone of vision, and they will not care.
Gameplay - Inventory Management Is Frustrating
Having To Drop everything between two objects to get it to a specific equip hot key got old fast.

The Good
Gameplay - Good Level Design
The level layouts are different enough that they are not repetitive but not too complex that you do not know where to go.
Gameplay - Variety In Content
The hiests are different so you do not feel like you are robbing the same store over and over.
Gameplay - Replay Ability
You can repeat each level to either try and get more loot, try not to kill anyone, etc.
Gameplay - Difficulty
The game was difficult enough so that you couldn't do a grand bank heist in two minutes, but not so hard that it takes an hour to rob a small shop.

Conclusion
In conclusion, I believe it's a great little game to kill some time, it reminds me of 'Payday 2' but in 2D, I had a lot of fun playing it.

Worth The Price?
I Got the game for ~£4.00 and for that price it is well worth it, but for the ~£14.99 asking price on steam, No, this is not a £15 to me.

For me, the main attraction in The Masterplan is the puzzle aspect of planning the heists, and the meta-campaign for building the your own criminal gang. The graphics are very pleasant to the eye, and at the same time clear enough for all gameplay purposes. Levels are well-made, although I'd welcome a bit more guidance of e.g. the recommended number of goons (in arcade, for example, you can't - at least I couldn't - carry all the money out with only 2 goons) and/or equipment such as bombs or the safe cracker thingy.

Actual gameplay is an addictive mix of calm planning, mixed with constant adjustments to the ever-changing chaos that is your heist. Several mechanics are fresh and make a lot of sense, such as the threat system. The UI feels a bit unforgiving to a novice: I shot a person a few times by accident, but judging by watching more experienced people play, I think that'll resolve itself in time.

I can't yet comment on the length or the ultimate challenge level of the campaign, but so far levels have been increasing in challenge constantly, which bodes well. Each mission so far have take only a decently short amount of time (15 minutes?), and require a few tries to succeed well. I'll most definitely be waiting to see the rest of the campaign, the rumored modding tools, and new developments by the team.

reviewText:
I had the pleasure of playing The Masterplan back in October 2014, during its Early Access phase. When I played the game then, The Masterplan was essentially a single player version of Payday. You had a crew and committed several heists. Every part of the plan was left up to you, planning, execution, and escape. There are new features in the game, the ability to hire goons,  buy weapons, and equipment, Including a new items that lead to other heists or weapon orders.

As of June 2015, The Masterplan has left Early Access and the game is now complete. I am happy to say the game is fantastic and fun. Everything here still works rather well as it did in Early Access, combat, sneaking, and general law breaking. In case your not familiar with The Masterplan, you control a team of criminals from a top down view. The best example is something like Door Kickers or a more far more tactical Hotline Miami. If things get a little hectic you can use a slow-mo button to issue commands and order your goons to perform tasks ranging from, shooting, taking hostages, or safe cracking.

Now while I covered most of how I felt about the game in my Preview(http://youtu.be/vefzlx_MtR8). I feel It's important to note how awesome the over all tone of the game is and how well it all works. While the graphics are simple they really do a good job of conveying the grit and crime of The Masterplan, almost in noir style. The music and sound effects are great and fit in perfectly as well.

For the purposes of this particular article, I wanted to cover the new things I enjoy and the things I wish worked a little differently. There is a story now intricately woven throughout the levels, little snippets of paper building the mystery of whats going on. There are cut scenes telling the tale of how your character broke bad during the Nixon administration. All of these add a little flavor and life to the game.

The hideout has seen a bit of updating as well. You now have the ability to hire goons and purchase weapons, as long as you have the right contact for the weapon. These can be acquired throughout the levels and add an extra objective aside from getting cash. This is all fine and works well but can lead the game to feel a bit grindey in the beginning as you have to repeat missions to earn enough cash. In later parts of the game this isn't a big deal. For the most part the hideout stayed the same, I would've liked to see a bit more added to it. Perhaps some sort of secret or way to expand upon it and make it the seat of your criminal empire. It just ends up being a stash place for your left over equipment/weapons and the place you go in between missions. Not a major complaint just my own personal wish.

There are several new missions and places to rob. Including new levels to finish out the story/campaign. All of these are crafted well and requires your keen focus as your order your team of goons. In general the gameplay felt smoother in controlling characters and maneuvering them, as opposed to the EA version of the game where it was a bit more difficult. Such things as being able to pass through your own men made things much easier. With that said there are still some things that are hard to control. Doors in particular are a nightmare and being such a vital element to the games strategy, I thought this would've been corrected a bit more.

Things such as goon skills and multiplayer have fallen to wayside or replaced with simpler mechanics. I feel that The Masterplan will benefit from simplifying and focusing on the single player experience. While goon skills would've been nice, that is something that perhaps can be added later. In the final version of the game the focus on singleplayer can be seen and the game is very enjoyable.
So if you haven't checked out The Masterplan yet and you're looking for a heist style game that is solely based off your skill. You definitely want to check out this title.

reviewText:
The bad.
I'm gonna start this review with the negatives. The Masterplan is a game I really truly wanted to love. But… I just can’t… First off the game feels too half-baked for a game supposedly out of early access. Examples, why are there two lockpicks you can find on one level but no more anywhere else? Why can I not view my goons stats after I hire them? Why can't I buy a bigger car? Why after the final score is the only way of exiting back to the normal game to quit to the main menu? It in turn doesn’t save the game from that score so you can technically never fully finish the game. You will still get achieves for it however. And why oh why does the game crash so much? 30 out of my 50 hours spent on this game have been afk for the last 3 nights trying to get the, “It’s my dayjob” achievement seeing how it’s the last one I need to get only to find in the morning that the game had crashed when it didn’t even have to do anything other than just sit there. Finally, I am running windows 8.1 and have a GeForce GTX 750 Ti 2gb version and yet in full screen mode I only get 30 fps where in Battlefield 4 I get 80 fps that can drop to 40 when intense events are happening. That should not be the case at all for a top down game with such basic graphics.

The good.
This game did provide me with some 20 hours of entertainment and I ended up beating the whole game. In this time there were some pretty fun moments. For example, when I used explosives to blitzkrieg the bank and later perfected my technique to blitzkrieg the casino. It is also pretty satisfying to go through all the work to clear a level and make off with the loot walking through the stealthy (or loud) chaos you’re leaving behind. Some other fun moments consisted of, holding up around 15 guards with 2 goons while my other 2 rounded up everyone else on the level, having a level without cops or cleaner costs where I basically stormed in with Uzis and murdered everyone, making off with the 4mil from the final score. Despite not being able to keep it was still fun. These are some examples of the good times you can have while playing this game.

Pros and Cons

Pros:
Fun top down gameplay.
Ability to hire and make a full sized crew.
Satisfaction of perfecting a plan all the way through (as long as it doesn’t crash!)
The ability to carry out a plan in such different ways really makes you wonder how you can approach each level.
Pretty original idea.

Cons:
Frequent crashes.
Low fps regardless of good graphics card.
Half-baked unfinished features. (example lockpicks)
Loud not a very practical option as you can lose up to 96% of your payout from cleaner costs alone.
Can’t view goon stats after hiring!
The game will never technically acknowledge you completed the final score outside of an achievement, but everything else for that score resets.

TL:DR/Summary
All in all this game is pretty fun at first providing a new and original idea. However, this game was yanked out of early access way to soon with too many unfinished features, and crashes to make it worth its $20 price tag.

Recommended?
No

reviewText:
Disclosure – I was given a review copy of the game by Shark Punch.

The Masterplan is a heist game set in the early 1970’s. You play as Joey Green. You are gunned down by corrupt police and left for dead. One thing however, you survived. You are in prison and have to escape. This level serves as the game’s tutorial. After this you meet up with your brother Gregory and start going on various heist missions.

Graphics

The graphics/visuals are done in a very interesting style. The game plays from a top-down perspective and the early 70’s vibe comes through in the game’s art.

Audio

The music sets the tone for the game. A very funky vibe scores the game as you go on your heist missions. Other sound effects include your standard gun fire, and punch sound effects.

Gameplay

The game shines in the gameplay department. You control Joey and his brother Gregory. You can move both at a time but will often need to control each of them separately to fully complete your missions. An early mission has you holding up a kiosk. You’ll need to keep the owner of the kiosk at bay by pointing a gun at him while you control your other character to empty the register. Sometimes you’ll need to knock a character out to obtain a key to get into the back room of a business. When holding up a character you can also control them and force them to open doors for you or complete other tasks.

During your missions you will find flyers that will unlock other heists throughout the city. New weapons can also be added to your catalog by finding flyers for them as well. You have a hideout where you can buy weapons or hire additional goons. These goons will help you on your heists, but for a price. Each goon has a set of attributes. The better the attributes the more expensive they will be to hire. Some goons even bring their own weapons along. The weapon catalog allows you to order the guns you’ve found flyers for in other missions.

The game can get challenging, especially when having to control multiple characters during a heist. If you should fail a heist you have the option to retry it. Some heists can also be done again once you’ve completed them.

Overall

Overall The Masterplan is a very fun game. It can become fairly challenging at times but the option to retry a heist is great. The controls take a little time to learn when you are dealing with using multiple characters at the same time. You’ll learn the controls fairly quickly though. This game is highly recommended.

The Masterplan is an entertaining game and concept, however the -constant- crashes at this early access stage ruins the fun, and I find it difficult to complete heists at times.

I partially want to discourage anyone to buy at this point, at least until the bugs have been ironed out and crashes are less frequent. However, I'm still recommending it because I believe the end product will deliver. If you like top down tactical games like Doorkickers and the theme of Payday 2 (yes this is being said all the time but I can't honestly find a better comparison to describe this game), this might satisfy you deeply on a strategical level.

The end product promises more features and interaction with your safehouse, which I'm looking forward to.
I already find the hostage mechanics engaging, and re-playing the hesists in order to make money doesn't feel as tedious as I had imagined.

My one wish for this game currently is for elements such as NPC paths, locations of essential items such as keys, and the location of the money/valuables themselves to be randomized each turn. It would create some variety between each attempt.

reviewText:
The Masterplan features a top-down view with slightly oversized characters. This view makes the environment you are robbing feel like an actual map as you can plot your movement from room to room while scanning the entire location.  The map/level design is the sort of addition that some may overlook as a basic visual style, but it really helps bring together some of the strategy needed to successfully complete a level without your fellow gang members dying.  The lighting is also a huge highlight of The Masterplan. As your characters creep around corners, you will see shadows of upcoming textures begin to reveal themselves. It helps round out a very solid environmental design.

During your heists, you will find weapon fliers hidden throughout the building that you must pick up and bring back to your hideout in order to unlock the weapon for purchase. This makes sense, but it would be nice to purchase some of the weapons a bit earlier, such as the silenced pistol, which is incredibly useful and would have been great to have access to from the beginning of the game. Then again, using a weapon can lead to less money as you are charged a “cleanup” fee at the end of each mission that is based on how many people you killed, with one kill cutting your overall pay in half.

When it comes to the members of your gang, permanent death is a thing to look out for. You can replace your goons by hiring more using the money you have acquired. The criminals you can hire will come with different weapons and varying statistics and specialties.
With the huge selection of locations available, it is hard to find yourself tiring of robbing each and every location you come across. The levels become infinitely more entertaining when you figure out the perfect plan that sees you getting past every guard and squeezing out every dollar possible.

The Masterplan’s in-heist gameplay is, without a doubt, the most frustrating part of the entire experience. While looking over the map and devising a plan is fun, it is tough to set that plan up perfectly due to the confounding controls. The controls are based all around the right and left mouse click, with the left selecting your goon and the right controlling pretty much everything else. At first, you catch yourself constantly trying to move with the left click. You can open up each character’s inventory by clicking on said character with the right click, which is also how you pick up items. Because of this, you will run into multiple situations that bring about a host of frustration as you struggle to tell your character you want to pick up the money in front of you as opposed to just opening up their inventory. Another incredibly frustrating aspect is when you are expected to perform a hold up on your enemy. In a perfect world, this would have you throwing your gun up at an enemy and them following your commands. But in The Masterplan, you must keep your visual cone on the enemy or they will go crazy and call the cops. Doing so is much harder than it sounds, as you will find yourself needing to order enemies around to unlock doors they have the key to. Once you order them to unlock the door, they tend to move outside of your visual cone. Establishing constant sight on them feels next to impossible, as you must hold down right mouse button on your character to rotate where you aim. Being unable to use the right mouse button can lead to frustration, which can ultimately lead to your entire plan falling apart.

THE GOOD
- Welcoming art style
- Lots of locations to rob, including a bank and arcade
- Decent amount of goons up for hire

THE BAD
- Frustrating inventory design
- Would be nice to unlock certain weapons earlier
- Clumsy controls

I played this game as far as I could, until the crashes got to me and I figured - screw it.

There are plenty of positive reviews that state what is good, and for the most part, I can agree with them. However, the following are the reasons that, for me, made me give up on this.


Firstly - The crashes. It crashed a lot. coupled with the fact that the game only seems to autosave AFTER the current heist is complete, it left me having to redo heists again and again - not fun.

Secondly - The way the character's inventories are handled; Right clicking on a character will bring up a circular inventory which surrounds the character. Sadly, the way you tell characters to pick up items/use items is also right clicking. This means that it is virtually impossible to pick up an item that the character is standing over, because you just continue opening a characters inventory. Not a great problem, just very annoying when it happens for the 7th time in 10 minutes.

Thirdly - This game is NOT a 'plan a heist' game. There is no 'casing the joint', for example - Its a puzzle game. When you find a solution to a heist, that solution will always work. It'll work for me. For you. It'll work a year from now. There is no random elements apart from, perhaps, the public that wander into the stores now and then. Not that that is a bad thing - but i didn't want a puzzle game. I wanted something more.

Fourthly - The whole hold-up mechanic. Seriously, If i have 2 guys with shotguns pointing them at a security guard, I don't expect that guard to wait 45 seconds or so, then draw his baton and charge me. But that's what happens. People will not be held up indefinitely, but instead you have a short time to either shoot them or beat them into unconsciousness.
Now, im aware that I didn't play THAT far into the game. Perhaps there will be items to permenently placate people - ropes or handcuffs - but I didn't see anything like that.


Don't get me wrong - Its not a terrible game. Its just has several flaws.

reviewText:
For those that don't know, or are interested in buying; The Masterplan is a top down strategy puzzle game. From appearance, it looks like a Payday: The Heist gone Door Kickers(but being the criminals) mixed with a crime-like aspect of Hotline Miami. .. with polished gameplay with many awesome features and unique and appealing graphics. There is a lot to this game and I'm going to try and cover most of it.

When I first bought this game, I was dissapointed. The first mission is quite confusing to someone who has never seen gameplay or a video of how it's done and the game's version of a 'tutorial' is confusing and quite unhelpful. This, being a con. However because of easy controls and UI you will figure it out within a minute or so. After you complete missions you go back to your hideout, which, is mostly pointless other than for you to mail order yourself weapons and accessories, or to hire another goon (Hitman/robber/whatever you want to call it). The more goons the better. Once onto levels with security you will want to hire another goon and make sure two of your three goons have guns. It takes two guns pointed at guard(s) to make their resistance level stay at 0 (Full circle), while your third goon beats them up. The gameplay is quite fluid and there is no pause button, but there is slow motion which is essentially the same thing except that the game is still moving. (reaaaaally slowww)
Due to the top down, slow paced aspect the game can probably run on any PC or laptop. The graphics aren't really changeable (Not like you would want/need to). And the game rarely crashes and doesn't ever crash on startup (for me, and I haven't seen any crash on startup reports on the forums). The developers and moderators on the forums, to those interested in the community, are very very nice. They seem to be open to critisism and are nice to the players and those asking questions on the forums. They reply to nearly every post, crash log, bug report, suggestion, etc etc.
Lets talk about how the game does in its genres.

Strategy 9/10. Very strategical, will have you dieing/running to your car from cops/shooting cops, picking places to hold people up, hide bodies, etc. Needs some working on the paths your goons follow but that is it.
Action 5/10. Not in 5 as bad but 5 as in it depends how you play. If you are the other 50% you will refrain from any 'action' and only hold people up and knock them out. If you are the other 50% you will be seeing lots of action, like shooting at cops, security, civilians, running to your car before the police show up, etc. So it heavily depends on how you choose to play.
Puzzle 4/10. Most people are probably suprised when I classified this as a Puzzle game, however, most players would agree. It's not really a puzzle game, it just has puzzle aspects of it. The whole mission is essentially a puzzle that you have to figure out how to get through a room and get the pieces inside of it using means of holding people up, telling hostages what to do, hiding bodies, locking doors and lots more. Since the game only has puzzle aspects, and isn't a puzzle game. So if you aren't into puzzle games, but this title has caught your eye, keep looking. If you are looking for puzzle games, this isn't one.
Now, to other qualities of the game..
Graphics 10/10. It has its own unique, and good looking style of graphics. Whereas, if you are looking for an HD clean realistic looking graphics, you won't find it here.
Bugs/Glitches 7/10. The game has bugs/glitches but they are few and far between. Most that get reported get patched that same day/week.
Gameplay 10/10. Challenging as hell, exciting, keeps you on the edge of your chair hoping you don't slip up and ruin your heist.

This game is unique, fun, challenging, appealing, and very exciting. If nothing I covered in this interests you, check out more reviews, gameplays, to get a feel of the game. If you still aren't interested, I suggest you look for a different game.

OVERALL: 9/10

reviewText:
GREAT GAME, very unique with strategy and some neat stealth. I got it when it was fairly Early Access and they have improved it since.

Its a mix of Doorkickers and Monaco or cartoon top down Payday-but with lots more stealth and way less FPS running and gunning which I don't care for much, thus like this game more in many ways.

Nice graphics, a decent number of maps (~15). Point and click, so no gamepad. Its fun locking guards in rooms, locking them out of rooms or after you enter or even locking a room to hide a body so they don't call for backup. Certainly not linear, play how and as creative as you want!  Take control of guards briefly or take those in your way out with a shotgun, tranquilizer or silencer. It can be very hard, challenging and sometimes frustrating.


NOTE:  FRUSTRATING, things like this happened a bit often (updates fixed it some) - 30 mins into a perfect heist at the Central BB Bank and it freezes up and ends my game (a save feature would help stop this waste of time) need to redo it all YET again just get the next level paper too! Far into every heist I have to hurry in fear of this having a error - not just dying or getting caught! This happens occassionally and it slows down (not the intentional planning feature) briefly despite being a basic game with the amount of content that shouldn't happen. Update, just completed the last mission (with just one person) and as I got in and drove away in 1 of the 4 bank trucks to complete the mission-error and the game closed again!

Otherwise its GREAT even with the tech flaws, hoping they make another one soon and continue to fix the remaining errors a bit more!

9.5/10 for a indie game and for what it sets out to do.
